text:
Hey guys, I'm currently developing a site using this beta tool :tada:

I'm getting a strange issue with the watch command. It seems that when it triggers on file change, it only sometimes uploads a complete file, most of the time it's empty. When saving simple html files with HubL, most of the time it uploads them empty and I have to rerun the watch command to push up a fresh set :thinking_face:
check your console where you’re running the watch
usually shows if there are any issues

Hey Glen, sorry you are having issues. So to confirm, occasionally you are getting blank files being uploaded to HubSpot?

Are you on a Mac or PC? Also, what text editor are you using?
Hi Glen, thanks for sharing this info! I also wanted to check --are you seeing any errors being output where your watch task is running?
is there a method for compiling into static html pages?
i'm coming from laravel with blade templating, so i'm looking for a method with the cli where it compiles locally so i can do dev here and then push my changes when i've got a working version.
I guess something like this <https://designers.HubSpot.com/docs/tools/local-hubl-server>, but this looks like it is outdated?

Unfortunately, you’re right, local-hubl-server is a little outdated at this point.

I’ve got a workflow set up that _sort of_ works for local development that I based off of this:
<https://github.com/Absanater/HubSpot-frontend-local>
It runs a version of a live page in browsersync so you can at least style locally

yeah, that's kind of what i was planning on doing. i'm trying to integrate tailwindcss into this project, so local dev is kind of important for purgeCSS to work, but i think i should be able to get it working by pointing it at the correct files.
I’m not really familiar with either, but that sounds pretty cool.  Wondering how purgeCSS would work with HTML outputted by HUBL.
Mostly asking because even though I’m not using a CSS framework, I’m currently trying to clean up some legacy styling and this would be a heck of a lot easier
is tailwind the "get rid of unused css" ?
If you only use modules in your templates purgecss will do it's job perfectly, otherwise you need whitelisting. I suggest to do that in the files and remove the comments afterwards.
